articles.headline: Data Leaks Shake Up Carbon Trade
articles.snippet: After a banner first year the carbon trading market has suffered a bout of nose dives, missteps and misreadings.
articles.abstract: After a banner first year the carbon trading market has suffered a bout of nose dives, missteps and misreadings.

articles.headline: Hussein Ruling Seems to Raise Execution Odds
articles.snippet: A five-judge panel approved charges of crimes against humanity against Saddam Hussein.
articles.abstract: A five-judge panel approved charges of crimes against humanity against Saddam Hussein.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 15 — Seven months into a trial he has turned into a theater of defiance, Saddam Hussein was confronted Monday with a formal legal indictment for crimes against humanity, an action that appeared to bring him a major step closer to the gallows.

articles.headline: Lens Cleaner Is Recalled Worldwide
articles.snippet: Bausch & Lomb recalled its lens cleaner because tests showed that it could leave consumers at risk for a potentially blinding fungal infection.
articles.abstract: Bausch & Lomb recalled its lens cleaner because tests showed that it could leave consumers at risk for a potentially blinding fungal infection.

articles.headline: China Lets Currency Rise Past Key Level
articles.snippet: The rise past the symbolic level of eight to the dollar unnerved regional investors who feared that it could open a path for broader declines in the dollar.
articles.abstract: The rise past the symbolic level of eight to the dollar unnerved regional investors who feared that it could open a path for broader declines in the dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, May 15 — China allowed its currency to strengthen past the symbolic level of eight to the dollar Monday, rattling Asian markets already shaken by the dollar's extended slide and Friday's drop in share prices in the United States.

articles.headline: From Russia, With Dread
articles.snippet: Mike Matthews, owner of a Russian vacuum tube factory, has encountered an increasingly common problem: someone is trying to steal his company.
articles.abstract: Mike Matthews, owner of a Russian vacuum tube factory, has encountered an increasingly common problem: someone is trying to steal his company.
articles.lead_paragraph: SARATOV, Russia — Mike Matthews, a sound-effects designer and one-time promoter of Jimi Hendrix, bought an unusual Russian factory making vacuum tubes for guitar amplifiers. Now he has encountered a problem increasingly common here: someone is trying to steal his company.

articles.headline: Justices Order Rethinking of eBay Case
articles.snippet: The long-running patent dispute between eBay and MercExchange entered a new and, quite likely, still not final phase on Monday.
articles.abstract: The long-running patent dispute between eBay and MercExchange entered a new and, quite likely, still not final phase on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 15  The long-running patent dispute between eBay and MercExchange entered a new and, quite likely, still not final phase on Monday when the Supreme Court sent the case back to the lower federal courts.

articles.headline: U.S. Levels a Final Blast at Enron Chiefs
articles.snippet: In closing arguments a prosecutor portrayed two former Enron chief executives as putting their own interests first while defrauding investors.
articles.abstract: In closing arguments a prosecutor portrayed two former Enron chief executives as putting their own interests first while defrauding investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, May 15 — A prosecutor accused two former Enron chief executives of "extraordinary arrogance" on Monday, and called them "masters of the cover story" who pushed the rules and crossed the line into illegality in their quest to portray Enron as a success.
articles.byline: By Alexei Barrionuevo and Simon Romero

articles.headline: U.S. Will Restore Diplomatic Links With the Libyans
articles.snippet: The decision ends more than 25 years of hostility while sending a strong signal to Iran and North Korea to follow suit.
articles.abstract: The decision ends more than 25 years of hostility while sending a strong signal to Iran and North Korea to follow suit.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 15  The Bush administration announced Monday that it would re-establish full diplomatic ties with Libya because Libya had abandoned its nuclear and other unconventional weapons programs and helped in the campaign against terrorism.

articles.headline: Bush Calls for Compromise on Immigration
articles.snippet: President Bush proposed a plan on Monday that could place up to 6,000 National Guard troops along the border with Mexico for at least a year, but he urged Congress to address illegal immigration in a way that maintains the nation's tradition of op...
articles.abstract: President Bush proposed a plan on Monday that could place up to 6,000 National Guard troops along the border with Mexico for at least a year, but he urged Congress to address illegal immigration in a way that maintains the nation's tradition of openness.     Stepping directly into the middle of a debate raging within his own party and in cities and towns across the country, Mr. Bush offered a menu of proposals on the issue, which has rapidly emerged as among the most challenging confronting Congress and the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 15 - President Bush proposed a plan on Monday that could place up to 6,000 National Guard troops along the border with Mexico for at least a year, but he urged Congress to address illegal immigration in a way that maintains the nation's tradition of openness.

articles.headline: U.S. Levels a Final Blast at Enron Chiefs
articles.snippet: A prosecutor accused two former Enron chief executives of ''extraordinary arrogance'' on Monday, and called them ''masters of the cover story'' who pushed the rules and crossed the line into illegality in their quest to portray Enron as a success....
articles.abstract: A prosecutor accused two former Enron chief executives of ''extraordinary arrogance'' on Monday, and called them ''masters of the cover story'' who pushed the rules and crossed the line into illegality in their quest to portray Enron as a success.     As the government began closing arguments in the Enron fraud trial, a prosecutor, Kathryn H. Ruemmler, portrayed Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay as image-obsessed chief executives who time and again put their own interests first while defrauding the company's investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, May 15 - A prosecutor accused two former Enron chief executives of "extraordinary arrogance" on Monday, and called them "masters of the cover story" who pushed the rules and crossed the line into illegality in their quest to portray Enron as a success.
articles.byline: By Alexei Barrionuevo and Simon Romero

articles.headline: Lens Cleaner Is Recalled Worldwide
articles.snippet: Bausch & Lomb said yesterday that it was halting worldwide sales of its ReNu With MoistureLoc cleaner for soft contact lenses because tests showed that its misuse could leave consumers at risk for a potentially blinding fungal infection.      The ...
articles.abstract: Bausch & Lomb said yesterday that it was halting worldwide sales of its ReNu With MoistureLoc cleaner for soft contact lenses because tests showed that its misuse could leave consumers at risk for a potentially blinding fungal infection.      The move followed the company's decision last month to suspend United States sales of the product after federal health officials linked an unusually high number of the fungus cases to use of the lens cleaner. Bausch & Lomb said it would encourage customers to switch to other lens cleaners in its ReNu product line.

articles.headline: Data Leaks Shake Up Carbon Trade
articles.snippet: It had a promising start, hailed by traders, policy makers and environmentalists as a way to curb global warming with the craft of capitalism. After a banner first year, though, the carbon trading market has suffered a bout of nose dives, missteps...
articles.abstract: It had a promising start, hailed by traders, policy makers and environmentalists as a way to curb global warming with the craft of capitalism. After a banner first year, though, the carbon trading market has suffered a bout of nose dives, missteps and misreadings, leading now to a clamor for major change.      It may be just growing pains. But it could point to big problems ahead in carrying out the dictates of the Kyoto Protocol, which many countries are counting on to manage climate change.

articles.headline: Justices Order Rethinking of eBay Case
articles.snippet: The long-running patent dispute between eBay and MercExchange entered a new and, quite likely, still not final phase on Monday when the Supreme Court sent the case back to the lower federal courts.      The justices told the lower courts to recons...
articles.abstract: The long-running patent dispute between eBay and MercExchange entered a new and, quite likely, still not final phase on Monday when the Supreme Court sent the case back to the lower federal courts.      The justices told the lower courts to reconsider whether eBay -- having been found by a jury to have infringed two MercExchange patents on the method behind the ''Buy It Now'' feature of its online auction business -- should be barred from continuing to use the method.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 15 - The long-running patent dispute between eBay and MercExchange entered a new and, quite likely, still not final phase on Monday when the Supreme Court sent the case back to the lower federal courts.

articles.headline: Behind Bush's Address Lies a Deep History
articles.snippet: The headline news from President Bush's immigration speech on Monday was troops to the border, but in substance and tone the address reflected the more subtle approach of a man shaped by Texas border-state politics and longtime personal views.    ...
articles.abstract: The headline news from President Bush's immigration speech on Monday was troops to the border, but in substance and tone the address reflected the more subtle approach of a man shaped by Texas border-state politics and longtime personal views.     In an effort to placate conservatives, Mr. Bush talked tough about cracking down on immigrants who slip across the United States' long border with Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 15 - The headline news from President Bush's immigration speech on Monday was troops to the border, but in substance and tone the address reflected the more subtle approach of a man shaped by Texas border-state politics and longtime personal views.

articles.headline: From Russia, With Dread
articles.snippet: Mike Matthews, a sound-effects designer and one-time promoter of Jimi Hendrix, bought an unusual Russian factory making vacuum tubes for guitar amplifiers. Now he has encountered a problem increasingly common here: someone is trying to steal his c...
articles.abstract: Mike Matthews, a sound-effects designer and one-time promoter of Jimi Hendrix, bought an unusual Russian factory making vacuum tubes for guitar amplifiers. Now he has encountered a problem increasingly common here: someone is trying to steal his company.      Sharp-elbowed personalities in Russia's business world are threatening this factory in a case that features accusations of bribery and dark hints of involvement by the agency that used to be the K.G.B.
articles.lead_paragraph: SARATOV, Russia - Mike Matthews, a sound-effects designer and one-time promoter of Jimi Hendrix, bought an unusual Russian factory making vacuum tubes for guitar amplifiers. Now he has encountered a problem increasingly common here: someone is trying to steal his company.

articles.headline: Hussein Ruling Seems to Raise Execution Odds
articles.snippet: Seven months into a trial he has turned into a theater of defiance, Saddam Hussein was confronted Monday with a formal legal indictment for crimes against humanity, an action that appeared to bring him a major step closer to the gallows.     Since...
articles.abstract: Seven months into a trial he has turned into a theater of defiance, Saddam Hussein was confronted Monday with a formal legal indictment for crimes against humanity, an action that appeared to bring him a major step closer to the gallows.     Since the trial began in October, Mr. Hussein has dominated the proceedings. He has used the platform afforded him by live television broadcasts across the Middle East to harangue the judges as stooges of the American occupation, lead walkouts and a hunger strike, and make long, disjointed speeches encouraging the insurgents fighting American troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 15 - Seven months into a trial he has turned into a theater of defiance, Saddam Hussein was confronted Monday with a formal legal indictment for crimes against humanity, an action that appeared to bring him a major step closer to the gallows.

articles.headline: U.S. Will Restore Diplomatic Links With the Libyans
articles.snippet: The Bush administration announced Monday that it would re-establish full diplomatic ties with Libya because Libya had abandoned its nuclear and other unconventional weapons programs and helped in the campaign against terrorism.      The decision e...
articles.abstract: The Bush administration announced Monday that it would re-establish full diplomatic ties with Libya because Libya had abandoned its nuclear and other unconventional weapons programs and helped in the campaign against terrorism.      The decision ends more than 25 years of hostility while sending a strong signal to Iran and North Korea to follow suit.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 15 - The Bush administration announced Monday that it would re-establish full diplomatic ties with Libya because Libya had abandoned its nuclear and other unconventional weapons programs and helped in the campaign against terrorism.

articles.headline: China Lets Currency Rise Past Key Level
articles.snippet: China allowed its currency to strengthen past the symbolic level of eight to the dollar Monday, rattling Asian markets already shaken by the dollar's extended slide and Friday's drop in share prices in the United States.     The actual rise in the...
articles.abstract: China allowed its currency to strengthen past the symbolic level of eight to the dollar Monday, rattling Asian markets already shaken by the dollar's extended slide and Friday's drop in share prices in the United States.     The actual rise in the Chinese currency was tiny: one-tenth of a percent from Friday's level. But the breaching of that threshold unnerved regional investors, who feared that it could open a path for broader declines in the dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, May 15 - China allowed its currency to strengthen past the symbolic level of eight to the dollar Monday, rattling Asian markets already shaken by the dollar's extended slide and Friday's drop in share prices in the United States.
